string $uri: The URI of the resource including the scheme. For user input that may correspond to a Drupal route, use internal: for the scheme. For paths that are known not to be handled by the Drupal routing system (such as static files), use base: for the scheme to get a link relative to the Drupal base path (like the <base> HTML element). For a link to an entity you may use entity:{entity_type}/{entity_id} URIs. The internal: scheme should be avoided except when processing actual user input that may or may not correspond to a Drupal route. Normally use Url::fromRoute() for code linking to any any Drupal page.

string $view_mode_id: View mode ID for the custom render pipeline this field view was destined for. This is not a regular view mode ID for the Entity/Field API render pipeline and is provided by the renderer module instead. An example could be Views' render pipeline. In the example of Views, the view mode ID would probably contain the View's ID, display and the row index. Views would know the internal structure of this ID. The only structure imposed on this ID is that it contains dash separated values and the first value is the module name. Only that module's hook implementation will be invoked. Eg. 'views-...-...'.

string|\Drupal\Component\Render\MarkupInterface $message: (optional) The translated message to be displayed to the user. For consistency with other messages, it should begin with a capital letter and end with a period.

string|\Drupal\Core\Database\Query\SelectInterface $table: The base table for this query. May be a string or another SelectInterface object. If a SelectInterface object is passed, it will be used as a subselect.

string|\Drupal\Core\Database\StatementInterface $query: The prepared statement query to run. Although it will accept both named and unnamed placeholders, named placeholders are strongly preferred as they are more self-documenting. If the argument corresponding to a placeholder is an array of values to be expanded (for example, with an IN query), the placeholder should be named with a trailing bracket like :example[].

string|\Drupal\Core\Database\StatementInterface $query: The query to execute. In most cases this will be a string containing an SQL query with placeholders. An already-prepared instance of StatementInterface may also be passed in order to allow calling code to manually bind variables to a query. If a StatementInterface is passed, the $args array will be ignored. It is extremely rare that module code will need to pass a statement object to this method. It is used primarily for database drivers for databases that require special LOB field handling.

string|\Drupal\Core\Database\StatementInterface $query: The query to execute. In most cases this will be a string containing an SQL query with placeholders. An already-prepared instance of StatementInterface may also be passed in order to allow calling code to manually bind variables to a query. If a StatementInterface is passed, the $args array will be ignored. It is extremely rare that module code will need to pass a statement object to this method. It is used primarily for database drivers for databases that require special LOB field handling.

string|array $key: Properties are often stored as multi-dimensional associative arrays. If $key is a string, it will return $temporary[$key]. If $key is an array, each element of the array will be used as a nested key. If $key = ['foo', 'bar'] it will return $temporary['foo']['bar'].

string|array $key: Properties are often stored as multi-dimensional associative arrays. If $key is a string, it will use $temporary[$key] = $value. If $key is an array, each element of the array will be used as a nested key. If $key = ['foo', 'bar'] it will use $temporary['foo']['bar'] = $value.

string|array $key: Values are stored as a multi-dimensional associative array. If $key is a string, it will return $values[$key]. If $key is an array, each element of the array will be used as a nested key. If $key = array('foo', 'bar') it will return $values['foo']['bar'].

string|array $key: Values are stored as a multi-dimensional associative array. If $key is a string, it will return empty($values[$key]). If $key is an array, each element of the array will be used as a nested key. If $key = array('foo', 'bar') it will return empty($values['foo']['bar']).

string|array $key: Values are stored as a multi-dimensional associative array. If $key is a string, it will return isset($values[$key]). If $key is an array, each element of the array will be used as a nested key. If $key = array('foo', 'bar') it will return isset($values['foo']['bar']).

string|array $key: Values are stored as a multi-dimensional associative array. If $key is a string, it will use $values[$key] = $value. If $key is an array, each element of the array will be used as a nested key. If $key = array('foo', 'bar') it will use $values['foo']['bar'] = $value.

string|array $key: Values are stored as a multi-dimensional associative array. If $key is a string, it will use unset($values[$key]). If $key is an array, each element of the array will be used as a nested key. If $key = array('foo', 'bar') it will use unset($values['foo']['bar']).

string|array $property: Properties are often stored as multi-dimensional associative arrays. If $property is a string, it will return $storage[$property]. If $property is an array, each element of the array will be used as a nested key. If $property = ['foo', 'bar'] it will return $storage['foo']['bar'].

string|array $property: Properties are often stored as multi-dimensional associative arrays. If $property is a string, it will use $storage[$property] = $value. If $property is an array, each element of the array will be used as a nested key. If $property = ['foo', 'bar'] it will use $storage['foo']['bar'] = $value.

string|array $text: The link text for the anchor tag as a translated string or render array. Strings will be sanitized automatically. If you need to output HTML in the link text, use a render array or an already sanitized string such as the output of \Drupal\Component\Utility\Xss::filter() or \Drupal\Component\Utility\SafeMarkup::format().
string|array $title: The page title: either a string for plain titles or a render array for formatted titles.
string|array $type: A string describing the type of the alterable $data.

string|array $type: A string describing the type of the alterable $data. 'form', 'links', 'node_content', and so on are several examples. Alternatively can be an array, in which case $theme_TYPE_alter() is invoked for each value in the array. When Form API is using $this->alter() to execute both $theme_form_alter() and $theme_form_FORM_ID_alter() implementations, it passes array('form', 'form_' . $form_id) for $type.

string|array $type: A string describing the type of the alterable $data. 'form', 'links', 'node_content', and so on are several examples. Alternatively can be an array, in which case hook_TYPE_alter() is invoked for each value in the array, ordered first by module, and then for each module, in the order of values in $type. For example, when Form API is using $this->alter() to execute both hook_form_alter() and hook_form_FORM_ID_alter() implementations, it passes array('form', 'form_' . $form_id) for $type.

string|false $destination: (optional) A string containing the URI that the file should be copied to. This must be a stream wrapper URI. If this value is omitted or set to FALSE, Drupal's temporary files scheme will be used ("temporary://").

string|int $maximum_dimensions: (optional) A string in the form WIDTHxHEIGHT; for example, '640x480' or '85x85'. If an image toolkit is installed, the image will be resized down to these dimensions. A value of zero (the default) indicates no restriction on size, so no resizing will be attempted.
string|int $maxlifetime Sessions that have not updated for the last maxlifetime seconds will be removed:

string|int $minimum_dimensions: (optional) A string in the form WIDTHxHEIGHT. This will check that the image meets a minimum size. A value of zero (the default) indicates that there is no restriction on size.

string|null $background: (optional) An hexadecimal integer specifying the background color to use for the uncovered area of the image after the rotation; for example, 0x000000 for black, 0xff00ff for magenta, and 0xffffff for white. When NULL (the default) is specified, for images that support transparency, this will default to transparent; otherwise, it will default to white.

string|null $langcode: Language code for the language of $text, if known.

string|null $langcode: The language code for the language the text is in, if known. When this hook is invoked during search indexing, the language will most likely be known and passed in. This is left up to the search plugin; \Drupal\node\Plugin\Search\NodeSearch does pass in the node language. However, when this hook is invoked during searching, in order to let a module apply the same preprocessing to the search keywords and indexed text so they will match, $langcode will be NULL. A hook implementation can call the getCurrentLanguage() method on the 'language_manager' service to determine the current language and act accordingly.
string|null $locale The locale or null to use the default:
string|null $name: (optional) The base file name (without the $type extension). If omitted, $module is used; i.e., resulting in "$module.$type" by default.
string|null $name: (optional) The name of the configuration object to reset. If omitted, all configuration objects are reset.
string|null $name: (optional) The name of the created property, or NULL if it is the root of a typed data tree. Defaults to NULL.
string|null $name: (optional) The name of the property or the delta of the list item, or NULL if it is the root of a typed data tree. Defaults to NULL.
string|null $name: The name of the main property, or NULL if there is none.
string|null $operator: (optional) The comparison operator, such as =, <, or >=. It also accepts more complex options such as IN, LIKE, or BETWEEN. If NULL, defaults to the = operator.
string|null $parameter: The parameter, or NULL to indicate all possible parameter values.
string|null $permission: (optional) A string containing a permission. If set, only roles containing that permission are returned. Defaults to NULL, which returns all roles.
string|null $reply: Optional email address to be used to answer.
string|null $sid: (optional) The ID of the items to remove from the search index. If omitted, all items matching $type are cleared, and $langcode is ignored.
string|null $source: (optional) Path that alias is to be assigned to.
string|null $source: (optional) The path to an image file, or NULL to construct the object with no image source.
string|null $table_name: The table name. Defaults to $this->bin.
string|null $text: (optional) The link text for the anchor tag as a translated string. If NULL, it will use the entity's label. Defaults to NULL.
string|null $timezone: (optional) The timezone to use, if different from the site's default timezone.
string|null $timezone: (optional) Time zone identifier, as described at http://php.net/manual/timezones.php Defaults to the time zone used to display the page.
string|null $type: (optional) The language type to reset as a string, e.g., LanguageInterface::TYPE_INTERFACE, or NULL to reset all language types. Defaults to NULL.

string|null $type: (optional) The plugin ID or other machine-readable type for the items to remove from the search index. If omitted, $sid and $langcode are ignored and the entire search index is cleared.
string|null $type: Limit the messages returned by type. Defaults to NULL, meaning all types. Passed on to drupal_get_messages(). These values are supported:

string|object $string: An HTML string or an object with a ::__toString() magic method returning HTML markup. The source HTML markup is considered ready for output into HTML fragments and thus already properly escaped and sanitized.
style: \Drupal\image\ImageStyleInterface image style being previewed.
style: Either 'asc' or 'desc', indicating the sorting direction.
style_id: The ID of the image style.
style_name: (optional) The name of the image style applied.
style_name: The name of the image style to be applied.
style_name: The name of the image style.

stylesheets: A two dimensional array, using the first key for the media attribute (e.g. 'all'), the second for the name of the file (e.g. style.css). The value is a complete filepath (e.g. themes/bartik/style.css). Not set if no stylesheets are defined in the .info.yml file.
stylesheets: Theme stylesheets.

sub_themes: An associative array of themes on the system that are either direct sub-themes (that is, they declare this theme to be their base theme), direct sub-themes of sub-themes, etc. The keys are the themes' machine names, and the values are the themes' human-readable names. This element is not set if there are no themes on the system that declare this theme as their base theme.

subject: Subject of the email to be sent. This must not contain any newline characters, or the mail may not be sent properly. MailManagerInterface->mail() sets this to an empty string when the hook is invoked.
subject: Subject of the email to be sent. This must not contain any newline characters, or the mail may not be sent properly. The subject is converted to plain text by the mail plugin manager.
submitted: Submission information created from author and created during template_preprocess_comment().
subtree: A fully built menu tree element or FALSE.
suffix: (optional) The form element suffix, may not be set.
suffix: The content to add after the <fieldset> children.
system_compact_link: Themed link to toggle compact view.
table: A draggable table for the language detection methods of this type.
table: A rendered table element of the group filter form.
table: A table of options for each field in this display.
table: HTML for the table of image anchors.
table: Table of field items.
table: Table of previously uploaded files.
table: The groupable filter table.
table: The project status table.
tabs: List of tabs for the toolbar.
tabs: Local tasks for the requested level.
tabs: Local tasks render array for the requested level.
tag: The HTML tag name to use; either 'th' or 'td'.
tag: The HTML tag name to use; either TH or TD.
tag: The tag name used by handler services to collect. Defaults to the service ID of the consumer.
tags: Provides link text for the next/previous links.

target: The database "target" against which to execute a query. Valid values are "default" or "replica". The system will first try to open a connection to a database specified with the user-supplied key. If one is not available, it will silently fall back to the "default" target. If multiple databases connections are specified with the same target, one will be selected at random for the duration of the request.
target: The database target name.
tasks: A list of maintenance tasks to perform. Each item in the list has the following variables:
teaser: Flag for the teaser state. Will be true if view_mode is 'teaser'.

template: If specified, the theme implementation is a template file, and this is the template name. Do not add 'html.twig' on the end of the template name. The extension will be added automatically by the default rendering engine (which is Twig.) If 'path' is specified, 'template' should also be specified. If neither 'template' nor 'function' are specified, a default template name will be assumed. For example, if a module registers the 'search_result' theme hook, 'search-result' will be assigned as its template name.
template: The basename of the template file to use, without extension (as the extension is specific to the theme engine). The template file is in the directory defined by 'path'.
template_file: A full path and file name to a template file to use. Allows any extension to override the effective template file.
template_preprocess_HOOK(&$variables): Should be implemented by the module that registers the theme hook, to set up default variables.
term: Taxonomy term of the current forum.
term: The taxonomy term entity, including:
text: (optional) The content to display within the <time> element. Defaults to a human-readable representation of the timestamp value or the datetime attribute value using format_date().
text: No HTML5 element, use a normal text field.
text: The heading text.

text: The link text for the anchor tag. If the hook implementation changes this text it needs to preserve the safeness of the original text. Using t() or \Drupal\Component\Utility\SafeMarkup::format() with @placeholder is recommended as this will escape the original text if necessary. If the resulting text is not marked safe it will be escaped.
text: The visible text used for the item link, such as "‹ Previous" or "Next ›".
theme path: (automatically derived) The directory path of the theme or module, so that it doesn't need to be looked up.

theme path: The effective \Drupal\Core\Theme\ActiveTheme::getPath() during \Drupal\Core\Theme\ThemeManagerInterface::render(), available as 'directory' variable in templates. For functions, it should point to the respective theme. For templates, it should point to the directory that contains the template.
theme: All installed themes.
theme: The machine name of a theme to use in the installer instead of Drupal's default installer theme.
theme_group_titles: An associative array containing titles of themes.
theme_groups: A list of theme groups. Each theme group contains:
theme_groups: An associative array containing groups of themes.
themes: A list of themes within the theme group. Each theme contains:
third_party_settings: (array) Settings provided by other extensions through hook_field_formatter_third_party_settings_form().
threaded: A flag indicating whether the comments are threaded or not.

throw_exception: By default, the database system will catch any errors on a query as an Exception, log it, and then rethrow it so that code further up the call chain can take an appropriate action. To suppress that behavior and simply return NULL on failure, set this option to FALSE.
tid: Taxonomy term ID of the current forum.
time: (optional) How much time Drupal cron should spend on calling this worker in seconds. Defaults to 15.
time: How long ago the post was created.
time: The formatted time ago when the site last checked for available updates.
time: The formatted time since the site last checked for updates.
time: Use a HTML5 time element type.
timestamp: (optional) A UNIX timestamp for the datetime attribute. If the datetime cannot be represented as a UNIX timestamp, use a valid datetime attribute value in attributes.datetime.
timestamp: Integer for the timestamp of when the node was last viewed.
timezone: (optional) String timezone name. Defaults to the timezone of the date object.
tip: Tip text.
tips: An array containing descriptions and a CSS ID in the form of 'module-name/filter-id' (only used when $long is TRUE) for each filter in one or more text formats. Example:
tips: Descriptions and a CSS ID in the form of 'module-name/filter-id' (only used when 'long' is TRUE) for each filter in one or more text formats.
title : The title of this group of rows.
title: (optional) A descriptive or alternate title for the link, which may be different than the actual link text.
title: (optional) The title of the element, may not be set.
title: (required) The human readable name of the ranking mechanism.
title: (required) The title of the menu link. If this should be translated, create a \Drupal\Core\StringTranslation\TranslatableMarkup object.
title: A descriptive title of the feed link.
title: A safe, translated string to use as the title for the progress page. Defaults to t('Processing').
title: A title to be prepended to the list.
title: Comment title, linked to the comment.
title: Node title.
title: RSS item title.
title: Text alternative for the forum icon.
title: The block title.
title: The book link title.
title: The displayed title of the link
title: The group heading.
title: The human readable section title.
title: The label's text.
title: The language negotiation type name.
title: The link text.
title: The localized title of the link.
title: The localized title of the operation.
title: The menu link title.
title: The name of the requirement.
title: The page title, for use in the actual content.
title: The parent book title.
title: The project title.
title: The radio button's title.
title: The section title.
title: The title of the book.
title: The title of the bucket, e.g. "Fields", "Filter Criteria", etc.
title: The title of the contextual link.
title: The title of the feed (as set in the view).
title: The title of the form element.
title: The title of the image.
title: The title of the list.
title: The title of the page.
title: The title of the project.
title: The title of the requirement.
title: The title of the table.
title: The title of this group of rows.
title: The title of this group of rows. May be empty.
title: The title text is displayed when the image is hovered in some popular browsers.
title: Title for the theme group.
title: Title of the <fieldset>, intended for use as the text of the <legend>.
title: Title of the column group.
title: Title of the feed item.
title: Title of the filter.
title: Title of the result.
title: Title of the view, only used when displaying in the admin preview.
title: Top level node title.
title_attributes: A string containing the attributes for the title.
title_attributes: HTML attributes for the page title element.
title_attributes: HTML attributes for the title element.
title_attributes: HTML attributes for the title wrapper.
title_attributes: HTML attributes for the title.
title_attributes: Same as attributes, except applied to the main title tag that appears in the template.
title_display: Elements title_display setting.
title_display: Title display setting.
title_prefix: Additional output populated by modules, intended to be displayed in front of the main title tag that appears in the template.
title_prefix: Additional output populated by modules, intended to be displayed in front of the view title.
title_suffix: Additional output populated by modules, intended to be displayed after the main title tag that appears in the template.
title_suffix: Additional output populated by modules, intended to be displayed after the view title.
title_suffix: Additional title output populated by modules, intended to be displayed after the main title tag that appears in the template.
to: The address or addresses the message will be sent to. The formatting of this string must comply with RFC 2822.
to: The mail address or addresses where the message will be sent to. The formatting of this string will be validated with the PHP email validation filter. Some examples:

tokens: An associative array of tokens. The outer array is keyed by the group name (the same key as in the types array). Within each group of tokens, each token item is keyed by the machine name of the token, and each token item has the following components:
toolbar_attributes: HTML attributes to apply to the toolbar.
toolbar_heading: The heading or label for the toolbar.
topic: An object with the raw data of the post. Potentially unsafe. Be sure to clean this data before printing.
topic: The topic object.
topics: An array of all the topics in the current forum.
topics: The topics to display.
topics_pager: The topics pager.
totalcount: Integer for the total number of times the node has been viewed.
translatable: (optional) A boolean value specifying whether this bundle has translation support enabled. Defaults to FALSE.
translatable: (optional) If the column group should be translatable by default, defaults to FALSE.

translation: For translatable content entities (if the 'translatable' annotation has value TRUE), define a class that extends \Drupal\content_translation\ContentTranslationHandler, to translate the content. Configuration translation is handled automatically by the Configuration Translation module, without the need of a handler class.
translation: The translation for the target language.

translation: This key (in the 'handlers' entity annotation property) specifies the translation handler for the entity type. If an entity type is translatable and no translation handler is defined, \Drupal\content_translation\ContentTranslationHandler will be assumed. Every translation handler must implement \Drupal\content_translation\ContentTranslationHandlerInterface.
trays: Toolbar tray list, each associated with a tab. Each tray in trays contains:
tree: A fully built menu tree containing an array. @see static::treeDataRecursive()
tree: The immediate children of the current node rendered as an unordered list.

type (optional): A 'needs-data' data type supplied by this token, which should match a 'needs-data' value from another token type. For example, the node author token provides a user object, which can then be used for token replacement data in \Drupal\Core\Utility\Token::replace() without having to supply a separate user object.
type: (automatically derived) Where the theme hook is defined: 'module', 'theme_engine', or 'theme'.
type: (string) The formatter to use. Defaults to the 'default_formatter' for the field type. The default formatter will also be used if the requested formatter is not available.

type: (string) The plugin (widget or formatter depending on $display_context) to use, or 'hidden'. If not specified or if the requested plugin is unknown, the 'default_widget' / 'default_formatter' for the field type will be used.
type: A string representing the type of task. This parameter has three possible values:
type: A string that defines the element type. The value can be 'option' or 'optgroup'.
type: Starting tag will be either a ul or ol.
type: The field type.
type: The machine name for the negotiation type.
type: The type of date field rendered.
type: The type of the element.
type: The type of the extension the original theme hook originates from; e.g., 'module' for theme hook 'node' of Node module.
type: Type of indicator: 'throbber' (default) or 'bar'.
type: a bitmask corresponding to the type constants in StreamWrapperInterface
type: whether it is for a module or theme. (Required)
types: A collection of all the available custom block types. Each block type contains the following:
types: A list of content types, each with the following properties:
types: An associative array of token types (groups). Each token type is an associative array with the following components:
ungroupable_table: The ungroupable filter table.
unique keys: (optional) An array of Schema API unique key definitions. Only columns that appear in the 'columns' array are allowed.
unique keys: The schema definition for the unique keys.
unpublished: An unpublished comment visible only to administrators.
update: The module is enabled and update.php is run.
updated: The modified date of the feed.
updater_name: The name of the Drupal\Core\Updater\Updater class to use for this project.
updates: A list of available translation updates.
updates: The projects which have updates.
upload_validators: An array of upload validators as used in $element['#upload_validators'].
upscale: If images larger than their original size can scale.
uri: Either the path of the image file (relative to base_path()) or a full URL.
uri: The URI of the image file.
uri: The URI of the image.
uri: URI of the source image before styling.

uri_callback: The same as the 'uri_callback' key defined for the entity type in the EntityManager, but for the bundle only. When determining the URI of an entity, if a 'uri_callback' is defined for both the entity type and the bundle, the one for the bundle is used.
url: (optional) If you have an external link use this element instead of providing route_name.
url: (optional) The \Drupal\Core\Url object to link to. If omitted, no anchor tag is printed out.
url: A \Drupal\Core\Url object.

url: A \Drupal\Core\Url to which to submit the Ajax request. If omitted, defaults to either the same URL as the form or link destination is for someone with JavaScript disabled, or a slightly modified version (e.g., with a query parameter added, removed, or changed) of that URL if necessary to support Drupal's content negotiation. It is recommended to omit this key and use Drupal's content negotiation rather than using substantially different URLs between Ajax and non-Ajax.
url: An instance of \Drupal\Core\Url for the operation URL.
url: An internal system path or a fully qualified external URL of the feed.
url: An optional \Drupal\Core\Url object.
url: An optional URL the image can be linked to.
url: Direct URL of the current node.
url: For a bar progress indicator, URL path for determining progress.
url: The \Drupal\Core\Url object.
url: The URL of the derivative image.
url: The URL of the license file/information for the version of the library used.
url: The URL of the original image.
url: The URL to this row's content.
url: The book link URL, instance of \Drupal\Core\Url.
url: The menu link url, instance of \Drupal\Core\Url
url: The project url.
url: The summary link URL.
url: URL of the current term.
url: URL of the result.
url: URL to the originating feed item.
url: a Url object.
url_is_active: Whether or not the link points to the currently active URL.
url_options: options passed to the \Drupal\Core\Url object when constructing redirect URLs for the batch.
url_title: The anchor text for the link.
use_operator: Checkbox to allow the user to expose the operator.
user: A Drupal User entity.
user_picture: The comment author's profile picture.
uuid: (optional) The name of the property that contains the universally unique identifier of the entity, which is used to distinctly identify an entity across different systems.

validate_format: (optional) Boolean choice to validate the created date using the input format. The format used in createFromFormat() allows slightly different values than format(). Using an input format that works in both functions makes it possible to a validation step to confirm that the date created from a format string exactly matches the input. This option indicates the format can be used for validation. Defaults to TRUE.
value (required): the string that is to be translated.
value: (optional) The current value (version, time, level, etc).
value: (optional) The requirement's status.
value: (optional) The value of the element, may not be set.
value: A string that contains the value attribute for the option.
value: The content of the list element.
value: The current value (e.g., version, time, level, etc). During install phase, this should only be used for version numbers, do not set it if not applicable.
value: The descriptive text for the forum.
value: The filters available values.
value: The required data type.
value: The textarea content.
value: The value to set. If set, it has to match one of the supported data type formats as documented by the data type classes.
variables: An associative array whose keys are variable names and whose values are default values of the variables to use for this theme hook.

variables: Only used for #theme in render array: an array of variables, where the array keys are the names of the variables, and the array values are the default values if they are not given in the render array. Template implementations receive each array key as a variable in the template file (so they must be legal PHP/Twig variable names). Function implementations are passed the variables in a single $variables function argument. If you are using these variables in a render array, prefix the variable names defined here with a #.
version: A list of data about the latest released version, containing:
version: Information about the module version.
version: The library version. The string "VERSION" can be used to mean the current Drupal core version.
version: The theme's version number.
version: The version number.
version: The version of the module.
versions: The available versions of the project.
view: A View object.
view: A ViewExecutable object.
view: Instance of the ViewExecutable object for the parent view.
view: The ViewExecutable object.
view: The view in use.
view: The view object.
view: The view that the field belongs to.

view_builder: For content entities and config entities that need to be viewed, define a class that implements \Drupal\Core\Entity\EntityViewBuilderInterface (usually extending \Drupal\Core\Entity\EntityViewBuilder), to display a single entity.
view_mode: The view mode being configured.
view_mode: The view mode, e.g., 'full', 'teaser', etc.
view_mode: The view mode; for example, 'full' or 'teaser'.
view_mode: View mode, e.g. 'full', 'teaser', etc.
view_mode: View mode; e.g., 'full', 'teaser', etc.
view_mode: View mode; for example, "teaser" or "full".

views_data: A class implementing \Drupal\views\EntityViewsDataInterface to provide views data for the entity type. You can autogenerate most of the views data by extending \Drupal\views\EntityViewsData.
views_query: Invoked when a field based views query is performed. The data key contains a reference to the field object.
visible: (optional) The default visibility of the element. Defaults to TRUE.
warning: Any warnings about why this module can not be updated.
weight: (float) The weight of the element. Not needed if 'type' is 'hidden'.
weight: (float) The weight to assign to the renderable element. Defaults to 0.
weight: (optional) An integer that determines the relative position of items in the menu; higher-weighted items sink. Defaults to 0. Menu items with the same weight are ordered alphabetically.

weight: Controls what order the Updater classes are consulted to decide which one should handle a given task. When an update task is being run, the system will loop through all the Updater classes defined in this registry in weight order and let each class respond to the task and decide if each Updater wants to handle the task. In general, this doesn't matter, but if you need to override an existing Updater, make sure your Updater has a lighter weight so that it comes first.
weight: Lower (negative) numbers come before higher (positive) numbers, for menu items with the same parent.

weight: Lower (negative) numbers come before higher (positive) numbers, for tasks on the same base route. If there is a tab whose route matches the base route, that will be the default/first tab shown.
weight: The default weight of the element.
weight: The weight of the contextual link.
weight: The weight of this operation.
where: The filter condition.
widget: Radio Buttons to select the filter widget.
widget: The widget object.
widget: The widget plugin instance.
width: The width in pixels of the derivative image in the preview.
width: The width in pixels of the derivative image.
width: The width in pixels of the original image in the preview.
width: The width in pixels of the original image.
width: The width of the image (if known).
width: The width of the image.
width: The width of the resized image.
width: The width of the source image (if known).

wrapper: The HTML 'id' attribute of the area where the content returned by the callback should be placed. Note that callbacks have a choice of returning content or JavaScript commands; 'wrapper' is used for content returns.
wrapper_attributes: A list of HTML attributes for the wrapper element.
wrapper_attributes: HTML attributes to be applied to the list wrapper.
wrapper_attributes: List of attributes for wrapper element.
wrapper_element: An HTML element for a wrapper.
zebra: 'even' or 'odd', used for row class.

trans-unit.source: @section_insert INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE queries INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE queries need special care in order to behave consistently across databases; you should never use db_query() to run an INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE query. Instead, use functions db_insert(), db_update(), and db_delete() to obtain a base query on your table, and then add dynamic conditions (as illustrated in Dynamic SELECT queries above).

trans-unit.source: @todo In fact the NativeSessionStorage class already implements all of the functionality required by a typical Symfony application. Normally it is not necessary to subclass it at all. In order to reach the point where Drupal can use the Symfony session management unmodified, the code implemented here needs to be extracted either into a dedicated session handler proxy (e.g. sid-hashing) or relocated to the authentication subsystem.
trans-unit.target: @todo In fact the NativeSessionStorage class already implements all of the functionality required by a typical Symfony application. Normally it is not necessary to subclass it at all. In order to reach the point where Drupal can use the Symfony session management unmodified, the code implemented here needs to be extracted either into a dedicated session handler proxy (e.g. sid-hashing) or relocated to the authentication subsystem.

trans-unit.source: @todo Matching on parameter *name* is not ideal, because it breaks encapsulation: parameter names are local to the controller and route, and controllers and routes can't be expected to know what all possible entity types might exist across all modules in order to pick names that don't conflict. Instead, the 'type' should be determined from introspecting what kind of PHP variable (e.g., a type hinted interface) the controller requires: https://www.drupal.org/node/2041907.
trans-unit.target: @todo Matching on parameter *name* is not ideal, because it breaks encapsulation: parameter names are local to the controller and route, and controllers and routes can't be expected to know what all possible entity types might exist across all modules in order to pick names that don't conflict. Instead, the 'type' should be determined from introspecting what kind of PHP variable (e.g., a type hinted interface) the controller requires: https://www.drupal.org/node/2041907.

trans-unit.source: A "deny all" grant may be used to deny all access to a particular node or node translation:

A "state" means a certain property on a DOM element, such as "visible" or "checked". A state can be applied to an element, depending on the state of another element on the page. In general, states depend on HTML attributes and DOM element properties, which change due to user interaction.
A 16 byte integer represented as a hex string formatted with 4 hyphens.
A 1to1 copy of parent::callMethod.
A 1to1 copy of parent::callMethod. Overrides ContainerBuilder::callMethod
A ; separated string ready for insertion in a HTTP header. No escaping is performed for HTML entities, so this string is not safe to be printed.
A MarkupInterface object cast to a string, the replaced value in the returned string be forcibly sanitized using \Drupal\Component\Utility\Html::escape().
A MarkupInterface object, the replaced value in the returned string will not be sanitized.
A \Symfony\Component\HttpFoundation\Response object.
A CSS asset grouper.
A CSS asset optimizer.
A CSS selector string for elements to which data will be attached.
A CSS selector string of the dialog to close.
A CSS selector string.
A CacheCollector implementation for building library extension info.

A Drupal schema definition is an array structure representing one or more tables and their related keys and indexes. A schema is defined by hook_schema(), which usually lives in a modulename.install file.

A Drupal schema definition is an array structure representing one or more tables and their related keys and indexes. A schema is defined by hook_schema() which must live in your module's .install file.
A JS asset grouper.
A JS asset optimizer.
A RFC7231 Compliant date.
A Route Provider front-end for all Drupal-stored routes.
A SelectQuery object to fetch the rows that should be inserted.

A URL for attempting to proceed to the next step of the script. The URL is not sanitized, so it still needs to be run through \Drupal\Component\Utility\UrlHelper::filterBadProtocol() if it will be used as an HTML attribute value.
A URL query parameter array that consists of all components of the current page request except for those pertaining to table sorting.
A base class for config entity types that act as bundles.
A base entity storage class.
A base exception thrown in any configuration system operations.

A batch process is used to check for po files at remote locations and (when configured) to check for po files in the local file system. The most recent translation source states are stored in the state variable 'locale.translation_status'.
A boolean stating that fields of this type cannot be created through the UI.
A boolean value to indicate whether this transaction has been rolled back.
A brute force tempnam implementation supporting streams.

A cache collector to allow the theme registry to be accessed as a complete registry, while internally caching only the parts of the registry that are actually in use on the site. On cache misses the complete theme registry is loaded and used to update the run-time cache.
A cache context service's name is used as a token (placeholder) cache key, and is then replaced with the string returned by this method.
A cache context token is either:
A cache of already-loaded routes, keyed by route name.
A cache of already-loaded serialized routes, keyed by route name.
A cache of information about blob columns and sequences of tables.
A callable that can be used to provide the entity URI.
A class for defining entity fields.
A class providing Drupal Twig extensions.
A class that defines a Twig environment for Drupal.
A class that defines a type of Attribute that can be added to as an array.
A class that defines a type of boolean HTML attribute.
A class that defines the Twig 'trans' tag for Drupal.
A class that defines the Twig 'trans' token parser for Drupal.
A class to format Diffs
A class to hold plural translatable markup.
A collector class for authentication providers.
A common interface for SQL-based entity storage implementations.
A compiled route contains derived information from a route object.
A config importer imports the changes into the configuration system. To determine which changes to import a StorageComparer in used.
A config object for the system performance configuration.
A configuration storage can contain multiple sets of configuration objects in partitioned collections. The collection key name identifies the current collection used.
A configuration storage can contain multiple sets of configuration objects in partitioned collections. The collection name identifies the current collection used.
A content entity database storage implementation.

A module can implement hook_theme_suggestions_HOOK(). This allows the module that defines the theme template to dynamically return an array containing specific theme hook names (presumably with '__' suffixes as defined above) to use as suggestions. For example, the Search module does this in search_theme_suggestions_search_result() to suggest search_result__PLUGIN as the theme hook for search result items, where PLUGIN is the machine name of the particular search plugin type that was used for the search (such as node_search or user_search).

A multidimensional array containing information about the module update dependencies. The first two levels of keys represent the module and update number (respectively) for which information is being returned, and the value is an array of information about that update's dependencies. Within this array, each key represents a module, and each value represents the number of an update function within that module. In the event that your update function depends on more than one update from a particular module, you should always list the highest numbered one here (since updates within a given module always run in numerical order).

A multidimensional array representing the dependency graph, suitable for passing in to Drupal\Component\Graph\Graph::searchAndSort(), but with extra information about each update function also included. Each array key contains the name of an update function, including all update functions from the provided list as well as any outside update functions which they directly depend on. A nested array of values to insert.

A plugin collection is a class that extends \Drupal\Component\Plugin\LazyPluginCollection or one of its subclasses; there are several examples in Drupal Core. If your plugin type uses a plugin collection, it will usually also have a configuration entity, and the entity class should implement \Drupal\Core\Entity\EntityWithPluginCollectionInterface. Again, there are several examples in Drupal Core; see also the Configuration API topic for more information about configuration entities.

A runtime assertion is a statement that is expected to always be true at the point in the code it appears at. They are tested using PHP's internal assert() statement. If an assertion is ever FALSE it indicates an error in the code or in module or theme configuration files. User-provided configuration files should be verified with standard control structures at all times, not just checked in development environments with assert() statements on.

A standardized prefix is useful to allow visual inspection of an APCu user cache. By default, this method will produce a unique prefix per site using the hash salt. If the setting 'apcu_ensure_unique_prefix' is set to FALSE then if the caller does not provide a $site_path only the Drupal root will be used. This allows WebTestBase to use the same prefix ensuring that the number of APCu items created during a full test run is kept to a minimum. Additionally, if a multi site implementation does not use site specific module directories setting apcu_ensure_unique_prefix would allow the sites to share APCu cache items.

APCu backend for the file cache.

APCu is a memory cache, shared across all server processes. To prevent cache item clashes with other applications/installations, every cache item is prefixed with a unique string for this site. Therefore, functions like apcu_clear_cache() cannot be used, and instead, a list of all cache items belonging to this application need to be retrieved through this method instead.
